title: Chinese GDP Drags Global Markets
text:
PSG Wealth Daily Investment Update, 21 October 2019

The JSE edged lower on Friday following the release of disappointing third quarter GDP data from China, fuelling fears of a slowing global economy. At the closing bell, the JSE All Share lost 0.48%Wall Street was on track for a weekly gain on Friday, but a disappointing performance by heavyweight Johnson & Johnson (NYSE: ) dragged the and indexes. Both lost 0.95% and 0.39% respectively.Poor earnings reports dragged European shares on Friday, rounding off an eventful week that left investors seeking new catalysts from Brexit and the US-China trade war. After the JSE closed, the lost 0.44% while the and also made losses of 0.17% and 0.65% respectively.Chinese and Hong Kong stocks fell on Friday after the release of a disappointing Chinese GDP growth rate. The economy advanced 6% y/y in the third quarter, slowing from a 6.20% expansion in the previous quarter. The closed 0.48% in the red.Japan’s surged to a 10-month high on Friday after technology stocks soared on upbeat earnings from Taiwan’s TSMC. At 19h40, the Nikkei recorded a 0.18% gain.The rand firmed on Friday as investors waited to hear government’s plan to rescue Eskom. At 19h45, a dollar traded at R14.76.Gold prices soared on Friday as less-than-inspiring Chinese GDP data fanned concerns of the extent of a protracted trade war on global economies. An ounce of traded at $1 490.23 at 19h50.Oil prices were mixed on Friday on bullish signals from both the Chinese and US refining sectors, while slowing global growth concerns dragged the markets. At 20h00, a barrel of traded at $59.56.
description: Market Overview Analysis by Adriaan Pask covering: USD/ZAR, FTSE 100, XAU/USD, S&P 500. Read Adriaan Pask's latest article on Investing.com South Africa.
